channel.description: Strategies to recover from stress quickly

item.title: A Path Beyond Self-Criticism to Loving Kindness
item.dc:creator: Jerry and Debbie Sheridan
item.description: One of the keys to feeling and functioning better lies in how we talk to ourselves. By changing our self-talk, we can alter both our feelings and our behavior. This is not mere opinion. Psychological research has confirmed it for … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
One of the keys to feeling and functioning better lies in how we talk to ourselves. By changing our self-talk, we can alter both our feelings and our behavior. This is not mere opinion. Psychological research has confirmed it for many years, even decades.

Many people believe that talking to themselves in nasty, critical ways will keep them in line, and somehow make them safe and prevent criticism from others. But it is in fact very damaging to your resilience, and is at the heart of our second most important factor influencing resilience.

We have already done a number of posts on reducing self-criticism (for example,click here), so there is no need to repeat ourselves. In brief, you have to become more aware of your self-critical remarks, then challenge them and devise more supportive remarks that are closer to the truth and/or more useful ways of thinking about yourself and the world.

This second factor was a problem because it had to be scored in “reverse”. That means you are less resilient the higher you score on that factor. When you criticize and tear yourself down, you make your reactions to stress worse, and that is the opposite of resilience.

We have long searched for the positive pole of this factor. When research on self-compassion came to our attention, it seemed to be that positive pole. But, more recently, we have realized that reducing self-criticism, which is very valuable, is, nevertheless, only a step in the direction of self-compassion.

To be compassionate toward yourself you have to go beyond reducing self-criticism and learn to be loving, caring, and understanding toward yourself.

In this series of posts, we are focused on taking steps beyond mere “sweet talk”, showing specific methods for getting to where you need to go.

For this post, we have chosen the Buddhist method of developing loving kindness toward yourself, then including others, then more and more of the beings in our world. This has worked for meditators for centuries, but there have also been quite a few experimental tests supporting the idea that it works.

The Buddha emphasized that you need only believe things that, when you try them, work out in your own life. So give this a try and decide for yourself.

We owe this video to the capabilities and generosity of Sharon Salzberg. (Expect a pretty long time lag before the video shows).

item.title: Why Do So Many Successful People Praise Failure?
item.dc:creator: Jerry and Debbie Sheridan
item.description: Nobody wants to fail, or, worse, BE a failure. Failure is associated with shame, financial ruin, living a harder life, diminished status, not being able to contribute to your family’s resources.… Yet, we often see and hear what appears to … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Nobody wants to fail, or, worse, BE a failure. Failure is associated with shame, financial ruin, living a harder life, diminished status, not being able to contribute to your family’s resources.…

Yet, we often see and hear what appears to be praise for failure. What could this be about?

People who praise failure are not really talking about a lust for failure; they are talking about an important role of failure in teaching paths to success.

They are also talking about how avoidance of failure, or refusal to acknowledge failure can keep you from understanding what went wrong with your ineffective tries, and thus from seeing how to do better.

Here is an example: Debbie and I often watch Fareed Zakaria’s weekly TV show, “GPS” (Global Public Square).  A week or so ago, he interviewed Sara Blakely, an attractive young woman who went from cold call sales of copy machines to creating a business that made her a billionaire. She invented Spanx, an undergarment  she says makes women look better. Obviously many women agree with her.

In that interview, Ms. Blakely talked about the important role of her father in teaching her what it takes to succeed. He taught his children to boldly try new things, and, when they failed praised them for the try and gave them a “high five”.  He taught them not to avoid risk, and to see failure as a positive aspect of life, a key aspect of adaptation to the world as it is.

When Charlie Rose interviewed renowned golf champion, Ben Hogan, he asked Hogan about how he reacted to one of his greatest tournament failures. Hogan said it was the best thing that ever happened to him.  He embraced his mistakes, and learned from them. Many other golf masters have made similar comments.

Placed in the context of the resilience factors we have been discussing in the recent blog posts, these highly accomplished people are expressing  attitudes that are resilient with respect to Factor One (Resilient Attitudes and Skills).  They respond to failures with resilient attitudes  of positivity and a problem-solving perspective.

In addition, they do not cut their legs out from under themselves with unreasonable self-criticism. So they have resilient qualities reflected in Factor Two (Self-Compassion versus Self-Criticism).

So what the “pro-failure” people are really saying is that we need to grant ourselves the space to learn from our mistakes. If we pass up opportunities in order to avoid risk, or deny our role in failure, we will not learn to adapt to the world we live in.

Making mistakes does not make us “losers”, but we have the option of interpreting our mistakes either in ways that make us lose or in ways that help us win.

Once again, we see the power of “Reappraisal”. If we see failure as an opportunity to learn, failure can be a positive influence. If we see it as humiliating, even unspeakable, or give ourselves no option other than to deny that it was our mistake, our adaptation to life will be thwarted.

We do not have to be afraid of making mistakes. Dealing with them is a known path to doing better in life.

Zorba the Greek said “Life is trouble. Only death is not. To be alive is to undo your belt and *look* for trouble.”

item.title: Resilience Factor Two: Hypersensitivity, Self-Criticism and What You Can Do About Them.
item.dc:creator: Jerry and Debbie Sheridan
item.description: The second most important resilience factor has to do with some very self-defeating things that people do that make them less resilient. It involves amplifying stress instead of getting it in control. I see it all the time; something distressing … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
The second most important resilience factor has to do with some very self-defeating things that people do that make them less resilient. It involves amplifying stress instead of getting it in control.

I see it all the time; something distressing happens and people react by tearing themselves down with self-criticism, and often go on to spread the criticism to, and generate fights with the very people who could help them recover quickly, which would be the path of resilience and both mental and physical health.

The core pattern of the factor was over-reacting to even small errors or failings by worrying about what we have done and how other people might react to our missteps. This leads to worrying about and criticizing ourselves for real or imagined failings.

This animation, voiced by Jennifer Lopez, may help you to see the kinds of criticisms and attacks we have in mind. Similar examples can be found here.

Our focus is on resilience, the positive things you can do to deal with stress and live a better life, so we are not interested in lamenting what is wrong with things we do, but with how we stay strong, healthy, and live well even if we have messed up.

We pondered and discussed Factor 2 (which we dubbed, perhaps clumsily, “Hypersensitivity, Self-Criticism/Perfectionism) for many years, frequently attempting to pinpoint the positive, resilience-promoting patterns implied by its negative, depleting ways.

Doing this blog and constantly looking for new approaches to enhance resilience led us to see what that resilience-promoting factor was.

We discovered an important body of research on self-compassion. If you are self-compassionate, you are not likely to be severely and unreasonably critical of your mistakes.

Self-compassion is the closest we are likely to find to the opposite of the intense and unreasonable self-criticism and demanding perfectionism reflected in Factor 2.

To give you a better sense of what factor two is about, here are some patterns embedded in it.

If you change on any of these patterns, you are also changing your standing on the factor itself. Here are more details:

  • Self-Evaluations that are Critical and Unreasonably Demanding versus Reasonable Self-Compassion, and Realistic yet Loving, and Accepting Self-Evaluations.
  • Worry/Rumination versus, Focusing on the Present, and Taking Things One at a Time.
  • Unreasonable Expectations/Perfectionism. The more resilient polarity of this is recognizing that we all have limitations and that errors are natural in human life and deserve compassion. Failures, handled well, can even help by teaching us better ways of managing our lives.

Knowing the factors is useful, but knowing ways you can change where you stand on them is more important. In a number of our previous blog posts we have discussed what to do if you need to improve on these patterns:

  1. Learn how to offer yourself warmth and non-judgmental understanding rather than belittling your pain or berating yourself with self-criticism. This previous post explains a useful way to reduce your self-negativity.
  2. The ordinary human mind is chaotic; there is ancient expression that “The mind is a drunken monkey”. If you are a strong self-critic, you need to help yourself become more even-minded, and meditation will do that. Here is one of our earlier posts on a very popular, effective method of meditation.
  3. Some things you can do to help with perfectionism are in this post.

item.title: Overthinking No More.
item.dc:creator: Jerry Sheridan
item.description: I don’t remember where I first ran into the concept of overthinking, but it appealed to me. Both Debbie and I understand the limitations of the parts of the brain that underlie thinking. We also are aware of the often … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
I don’t remember where I first ran into the concept of overthinking, but it appealed to me. Both Debbie and I understand the limitations of the parts of the brain that underlie thinking. We also are aware of the often unrecognized strengths of the “emotional brain”, which is commonly regarded as a giving birth to mere “fluff”.

Emotion is certainly not “fluff”. Antonio and Hannah Da Massio have shown that we need cooperation between the emotional brain and the thinking brain in order to deal with the real world. They showed that people with brain injuries that left both their thinking and their emotional brains intact, but blocked them from cooperating with each other resulted in smart people with extremely poor judgment.

These people could do very well on IQ tests, and even give intelligent answers to questions like “How many giraffes are there in the United States” that require creative and complicated thinking strategies.

So, when I ran into several articles about overthinking, I already knew that placing too much emphasis on thinking and too little on feeling and emotions would lead to poor outcomes. So the word “overthinking” grabbed my attention.

The go-to book on overthinking is one called “Women Who Think Too Much” by Prof. Susan Noel-Hoeksema. (Why just women? She pointed out that women are more likely than men to overthink. That is true, but actually, the few available research sources indicate a small, though statistically significant difference. So the book is also useful for guys).

As I began working my way through the book, I was impressed, and I recommended it to Debbie.

But, eventually I saw that reading the book is like taking a ride on a roller coaster, with the excitement and fun of learning alternating with pages of tedium. (This was my experience, not necessarily the objective truth.)

The best thing about the book is that it is full of methods for reducing overthinking.

So, here is my take:

What is overthinking? Professor Noel-Hoeksema describes it as “going over and over your negative thoughts and feelings, kneading them like dough. She applies the term the “yeast effect”.  “Just as yeasty bread dough will double in size after it’s been kneaded, our negative thoughts expand, grow, and begin to take up all the space around them in our minds.”

We have always emphasized the damaging effects of stress amplification in limiting resilience. That last thing you should do when times are harsh is to alienate your supporters, tear yourself down, exaggerate your hopelessness… You get the idea- when you are in a distressing situation, you need someone who is on your side, but also smart about what helps and what hurts.

Clearly it doesn’t sound like a good thing to overthink. Research has linked it to depression. “When sadness is amplified instead of managed, it can take you down paths to hopelessness, self-hate, and immobility.”

It also increases anxiety, which can lead to a nasty physiological and psychological avalanche, ending in chronic arousal that “wears down the body” and eventually makes it hard for you to deal with even mildly challenging situations. All we can say is “Amen”.

So what can you do about overthinking? Here is a mix of examples from her book and some others that we think are also useful:

  • Look for interpretations of distressing events that are not as damning as the ones that first come to mind.  Could nasty, critical comments about you be wrong, even silly and more about the critic than about you?
  • You should accept and attend to your negative feelings. But don’t be ruled by them. This is possibly the most important thing you can learn about scary feelings; you can have them and just keep going with what you judge to be in your best interest.
  • Don’t wait for someone else to rescue you; get going on ways to take care of yourself. Focus on what you can do for yourself, and if someone else helps, be thankful for their caring, but realize that it is the delicious frosting on the cake.
  • Brainstorm for possible ways to change your situation. The first few solutions you come up with are probably a tiny fraction of what you can discover if you unleash your creativity.
  • Start with something small. Small change adds up.
  • Don’t let uncertainly stop you from acting. Move forward even though you are uncertain about whether your solution will work. Doing something at the very least gives you dignity.
  • When you are having catastrophic thoughts about yourself, ask if these thoughts are merely echoing the unsupportive words of others who spoke without looking out for your interests.
  • Focus on your feelings, attend to what you are feeling in your body. This is usually the best source of what you really need to know in order to find an answer that can help you.
  • Don’t forget to exercise, even if it is for only a few minutes per day. Exercise improves
    • Stress-related aspects of your physiology.
    • The positivity and clarity of your thoughts.
    • Your level of calmness.

item.title: Depressed, Anxious, Being Hard on Yourself? New Insights about the Value of Learning to Be both Self-Compassionate and Self-Soothing.
item.dc:creator: Jerry Sheridan
item.description: Most of us are aware that we have an inner critic that can make it hard to enjoy life, and, in the more severe instances, induce such things as anxiety and depression. We have written several posts about the inner … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Most of us are aware that we have an inner critic that can make it hard to enjoy life, and, in the more severe instances, induce such things as anxiety and depression.

We have written several posts about the inner critic and how to deal with it through changing your inner self-talk.

We have also encouraged the use of mindfulness meditation. With mindfulness we observe the flow of our experiences with compassion and acceptance, the opposite of self-criticism.

This post is about an important new insight into what it may take to stop unhelpful self-criticism. It involves learning to be compassionate toward the inner critic, which is, after all, an aspect of ourselves. This means to understand that the self-criticism is something you learned in order to adapt to the environment in which you grew up.

In addition we must also learn ways to sooth ourselves.

According to British psychologist, Paul Gilbert, besides reducing the critical self-talk, we need to shift from feelings of “self-directed hostility, contempt, and self-loathing” to   “feelings of self-reassurance, warmth, and self-soothing”.

“Some high self-critics could understand the logic of CBT and generate alternative thoughts to self-criticism but rarely felt reassured by such efforts”.  (CBT is cognitive behavior therapy; a self-help version can be found here.)

In his view, besides changing our self-talk, many of us need to learn ways to sooth ourselves, and thus to experience the warm feelings that accompany self-compassion and self-soothing.

But how do we do that?  Check out our post on “Natural Stress Defeaters” for some simple methods of self-soothing that have worked for others, and that you can easily bring into your own life. Also deep relaxation produces feelings of relaxation and warmth, and it, too, is easy to fit into your life. The previous link has a free audio that is designed to help you to feel warmer and more at peace.

Dr. Gilbert provides many mental exercises crafted to induce the desired feelings of warmth and peacefulness. They can be found in his book “The Compassionate Mind”.

item.title: From Negative Thinking and Self-Criticism to Positive Thinking and Self-Compassion
item.dc:creator: Jerry Sheridan
item.description: In this post we provide some guidance on how to deal with your inner critic. Being self-critical rather than being compassionate toward yourself is the second greatest component of resilience. Yet most people suffer from the persistent though often questionable … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
In this post we provide some guidance on how to deal with your inner critic. Being self-critical rather than being compassionate toward yourself is the second greatest component of resilience. Yet most people suffer from the persistent though often questionable claims of their “inner critic”.

This video exposes the inner critic at work.

When I first heard the criticisms in this animation, I was almost overwhelmed by them. It took a while for me to see how to fight back against them. It is one thing to hear the words, but the emotional tone greatly intensifies their power.

Lest you think this is an unrealistic portrayal of self-criticism, here are things Major League pitchers used to describe themselves: “idiot,” “loser,” “dummy,” “gutless,” and “I stink,” “I can’t,” “I don’t have it,” and “I’m clueless.” Keep in mind that major league pitchers are a VERY highly selected for their outstanding talent and performance.

Obviously, it is demoralizing to have statements like these hurled at you, even though you are the person who hurls them.

The legendary Rabbi Hillel said “”If I am not for myself, who will be for me? And if I am only for myself, what am I? And if not now, when?”

Almost anyone can see this is wisdom in its clearest form. Yet, so many of us are not “for ourselves”.

What can we do about this?

The research and clinical experience of psychologists shows us several ways to deal with negativity and self-criticism.

  1. First we have to bring our negative, self-critical  thoughts into the light of consciousness in order to learn whether they make sense and have a reasonable claim to guiding us.
  2. Next we have to target the ones that undermine us the most, and boldly question whether they are solidly based In reality and can lead to realistic changes in how we live our lives.

Take the accusation, “You’re too fat”.

Is it true? Anorexics think they are too fat, and they are as emaciated as people in concentration camps; they are literally starving themselves to death.

I used to teach college classes that included the topics of obesity and weight control. Students, particularly women, who appeared to be of normal weight seemed more intensely interested in this topic than any other that I covered.

Even if we are overweight, shouldn’t people be judged by the content of their character, not the appearance of their body?

Assuming you rationally decide you’re too fat, what good is it to criticize yourself? People can spend a lifetime telling themselves they are too fat, and still gain weight all along. What evidence is there that attacking yourself helps you lose fat? There is actually a lot of evidence that such “aversive control” is remarkably ineffective.

There is also a lot of evidence that our thoughts are often a poor reflection of reality. We fail miserably to estimate how bad we will feel when things fail to go the way we want, and how good we will feel when things go the way we want them to go. Nobel prize winning psychologist Daniel Kahneman has written a currently best-selling book chock full of examples of how far our minds fall short of what is real. So if our thoughts aren’t USEFUL to us, it makes sense to question their value.

The accusation “You’re stupid. STUPID!”

What is the evidence for this? Did you get adequate grades in school? Is there anything you do competently? On the surface this accusation sounds like an assessment of your intelligence, but the underlying meaning is that the critic despises you and wants to undermine your confidence.

And “You’re too ugly, to short, no fun. Loser! LOSER!!”

Hmm. To me these accusations follow a familiar pattern in which someone grabs anything they can think of to hurt you. Sometimes they even say irrelevant things Like “Your uncle John is a liar and a thief!”

The novelist, Somerset Maugham had a club foot. He once said that when he was in conflict with others, they had all, without exception, made mention of his club foot. When attacking others or themselves people tend to reach for anything, real or imagined, that is likely to hurt.

Many people think that they have to be self-critical lest they become under-achievers. The evidence for this is, to say the least, weak.

On the other hand, the opposite of self-criticism, self-compassion, is known to have positive results. Here are the two best things you can do to shift from self-criticism to self-compassion:

  1. Train yourself to critique the claims of you inner critic.
  2. Develop and put into practice skills of self-soothing.

To deal effectively with life, we must learn to reject unsupported claims against us, even when they come from inside our heads, and to develop habits of calming and soothing ourselves.

item.title: Self-Compassion and Resilience
item.dc:creator: Jerry Sheridan
item.description: Earlier, I explained that there are three factors that indicate whether people are resilient. For this post, I want to go back to the second resilience factor, discussed previously, about not being too hard on yourself. Many of us attack … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
Earlier, I explained that there are three factors that indicate whether people are resilient. For this post, I want to go back to the second resilience factor, discussed previously, about not being too hard on yourself.

Many of us attack ourselves when we are down. Here are some words Harvey Dorfman, a major league pitching coach heard his extremely talented athletes apply to themselves: “idiot,” “loser,” “dummy,” “gutless,” and “I stink,” “I can’t,” “I don’t have it,” and “I’m clueless.” Notice that these are nasty and inaccurate. Even if on a given occasion they had made a mistake, they wouldn’t be major league pitchers if they were losers, idiots, etc.

Recently Glamor Magazine did a survey of women’s attitudes toward their bodies, and here are some things the surveyed women had to say about themselves: “You are a fat, worthless pig.” “You’re too thin. No man is ever going to want you.” “Ugly. Big. Gross.” Ninety-seven percent of surveyed women had at least one such thought per day and, on average, the women had close to one of these thoughts per waking hour.

As a full-time professor I used to lecture on overweight, obesity, and weight loss. I always marveled at the intense attention students, especially women, gave as I spoke. Very lovely, well-formed women whom any sensible person would see as attractive were intensely interested in how to lose weight. And they were more than willing to listen to a paunchy professor tell them how to do that!

People who tend to speak abusively to themselves diminish their level of resilience, and so presumably lose at least some of the many advantages of being resilient. We are talking, after all, about the second most important resilience factor.

If, when under stress, we are nasty to ourselves, we just ratchet up the mental and physical stress reactions, and slow our recovery.

Recently the New York Times ran an article centering on the work of Kristin Neff on Self-Compassion. By going to Dr. Neff’s website, I saw that this topic has been the subject of a lot of research, not just by her, but by many others. Somehow I had missed it, despite my constant efforts to find everything relevant to resilience.

Her work took me one step further in clarifying what that second resilience factor is. It is about being compassionate toward yourself. To me that feels richer than merely putting an end to being mean to yourself. Compassion is not just the absence of meanness. It implies treating yourself in a caring, understanding, and loving way.

I am going to end this post with a valuable quotation from a paper by Dr. Neff that clarifies the concept of self-compassion:

“If individuals are self-compassionate when confronting suffering, inadequacy or failure, it means that they offer themselves warmth and non-judgmental understanding rather than belittling their pain or berating themselves with self-criticism.”

item.title: To Increase Your Resilience, Avoid Being Too Hard On Yourself.
item.dc:creator: Jerry Sheridan
item.description: In a previous post we described the three core factors that underlie resilience. Mostly we have talked about the first factor. The second factor has to do with: Treating your minor mistakes as awful and catastrophic. Being excessively self-critical. Setting … Continue reading →
item.content:encoded:
In a previous post we described the three core factors that underlie resilience. Mostly we have talked about the first factor. The second factor has to do with:

  1. Treating your minor mistakes as awful and catastrophic.
  2. Being excessively self-critical.
  3. Setting unrealistically high standards that are usually unattainable.

In plain language, it is being too hard on yourself. It is very likely to make you less resilient and more vulnerable.

The three item list above is identical to what many researchers who explore this topic simply call “perfectionism” or “maladaptive perfectionism”.

Perfectionists cannot tolerate even the smallest mistakes, berate themselves for any slip ups, and view results that are less than perfect as completely unacceptable. Clearly, perfectionism can make anything stressful.

The resilience-training alternatives to these three items are

1.                Learning to treat your minor mistakes realistically, with tolerance and acceptance.

2.                Learning to question and forcefully challenge the self-critical voice inside you, replace the criticism with ideas about how to do better in the future.

3.                Learning that having unrealistically high standards is not admirable or a path to success.

There are many levels of perfectionism. The severe ones are best dealt with in treatment with a qualified therapist. For example, perfectionistic people who are so thwarted that they have become severely depressed should consider therapy. That doesn’t exclude self-training. In fact, therapists commonly refer clients to our resilience training, as an adjunct to their therapy.

Most of us who stress ourselves by being too perfectionistic can improve considerably in one of two ways:

1.                Regularly and steadfastly challenging thoughts that point to unfair and unrealistic internal demands. If, when you make a mistake, your inner critic claims you are stupid or your action is going to result in catastrophic losses, or even that you would be better off dead, don’t take that lying down. Be your own defense attorney and demand solid evidence for the critic’s claims.

2.                Practicing some form of mindfulness meditation.

Here is a good account of how to challenge and diminish your self-critical thoughts. In the next post we will describe our preferred method of mindfulness meditation. You should also take a look at the book “The Pursuit of Perfect: How to Stop Chasing Perfection and Start Living a RICHER, HAPPIER Life”, by Tal Ben-Shahar. It is a book with heart, combining a narrative of his personal struggle to overcome perfectionism with science-based, helpful techniques.
